Lessons.Name: Python
Lessons.Content:
Python

Python is a "high-level" programming language and its core design philosophy is all about code readability and a syntax which allows programmers to express concepts in a few lines of code” created by Guido van Rossum.

In this course we will use an online code editor so no installation required.

Hello World

In our academy page, switch to code view and type

print("Hello Python!")

https://repl.it/@mokhleselheni/HelloPython?lite=true

Slides.Name: Variables
Slides.Content:
Variables

You can think about variables as a box that stores a value. Simple as that.

# booleans
true_boolean = True # T (uppercase) not t!
false_boolean = False # F not f!

# string
my_name = "Leandro Tk"

# float
book_price = 15.80

Slides.Name: Conditions
Slides.Content:
Control Flow: conditional statements

If a condition is True do something otherwise do another thing else.

if 1 > 2:
  print("1 is greater than 2")
else:
  print("1 is not greater than 2")

You can also use “elif” statement. Like that:

if 1 > 2:
  print("1 is greater than 2")
elif 2 > 1:
  print("1 is not greater than 2")
else:
  print("1 is equal to 2")

Slides.Name: Looping
Slides.Content:
Execute n lines of code until the condition turn to False

num = 1

while num <= 10:
  print(num)
  num += 1

For each element of a list do something

for i in range(1, 11):
  print(i)
  • range is a function that return a list from the first arg to 2nd (the 2nd not included).

Exercise

Ask the user to enter two integers (x and y) both should be greater than 0. Print which integer is bigger x or y.

Slides.Name: Lists
Slides.Content:
List: Collection | Array

my_integers = [5, 7, 3, 4, 4]

To take an element of the array and manipulate it we use indexes like this

print(my_integers[0]) # 5
print(my_integers[1] + my_integers[4]) # 7 + 4 = 11

To add an element to our list we use append()

bookshelf = []
bookshelf.append("The Effective Engineer")
bookshelf.append("The 4 Hour Work Week")
print(bookshelf[0]) # The Effective Engineer
print(bookshelf[1]) # The 4 Hour Work Week

Tuples

Lists that cannot be changed, just another thing () in place of [].

  a = (1, 2, "string", [])
  print(a[2])

Slides.Name: Dicts
Slides.Content:
Dictionary: Key-Value Data Structure

dictionary_example = {
  "key1": "value1",
  "key2": "value2",
  "key3": "value3"
}

Now we manipulate an element of our Dictionary using its key:

print("My name is %s" %(dictionary_tk["name"])) # My name is Leandro

Looping a Dictionary

for key, value in dictionary.items():
    print("%s --> %s" %(key, value))

Exercise:

Create a French to English Translator.

https://repl.it/@mokhleselheni/DictFrToEn?lite=true

Slides.Name: Function and Classes
Slides.Content:
Functions

def sum_of_2(arg1, arg2):
  result = arg1 * arg2
  return result

res = sum_of_2(2, 3)
print(res)

OOP

class Vehicle:
  def __init__(self, number_of_wheels, type_of_tank, seating_capacity, maximum_velocity):
    self.number_of_wheels = number_of_wheels
    self.type_of_tank = type_of_tank
    self.seating_capacity = seating_capacity
    self.maximum_velocity = maximum_velocity

  def number_of_wheels(self):
    return self.number_of_wheels

  def set_number_of_wheels(self, number):
    self.number_of_wheels = number

  def make_noise(self):
    print('VRUUUUUUUM')

Using this class

tesla_model_s = Vehicle(4, 'electric', 5, 250)
tesla_model_s.make_noise() # VRUUUUUUUM

Exercise

Write a student class (Name, Mark) with one method which return if the student pass/fail the test (mark >=? 10)

https://repl.it/@mokhleselheni/Student?lite=true

Slides.Name: Mini Project
Slides.Content:
Your work

Complete the code to make a simple AI that can play with the user the game of Tic Tac Toe.

For each element of a list do something

for i in range(1, 11):
  print(i)
  • range is a function that return a list from the first arg to 2nd (the 2nd not included).

Exercise

Ask the user to enter two integers (x and y) both should be greater than 0. Print which integer is bigger x or y.

Slides.Name: Lists
Slides.Content:
List: Collection | Array

my_integers = [5, 7, 3, 4, 4]

To take an element of the array and manipulate it we use indexes like this

print(my_integers[0]) # 5
print(my_integers[1] + my_integers[4]) # 7 + 4 = 11

To add an element to our list we use append()

bookshelf = []
bookshelf.append("The Effective Engineer")
bookshelf.append("The 4 Hour Work Week")
print(bookshelf[0]) # The Effective Engineer
print(bookshelf[1]) # The 4 Hour Work Week

Tuples

Lists that cannot be changed, just another thing () in place of [].

  a = (1, 2, "string", [])
  print(a[2])

Slides.Name: Dicts
Slides.Content:
Dictionary: Key-Value Data Structure

dictionary_example = {
  "key1": "value1",
  "key2": "value2",
  "key3": "value3"
}

Now we manipulate an element of our Dictionary using its key:

print("My name is %s" %(dictionary_tk["name"])) # My name is Leandro

Looping a Dictionary

for key, value in dictionary.items():
    print("%s --> %s" %(key, value))

Exercise:

Create a French to English Translator.

https://repl.it/@mokhleselheni/DictFrToEn?lite=true

Slides.Name: Mini Project
Slides.Content:
Your work

Complete the code to make a simple AI that can play with the user the game of Tic Tac Toe.

Slides.Name: Function and Classes
Slides.Content:
Functions

def sum_of_2(arg1, arg2):
  result = arg1 * arg2
  return result

res = sum_of_2(2, 3)
print(res)

OOP

class Vehicle:
  def __init__(self, number_of_wheels, type_of_tank, seating_capacity, maximum_velocity):
    self.number_of_wheels = number_of_wheels
    self.type_of_tank = type_of_tank
    self.seating_capacity = seating_capacity
    self.maximum_velocity = maximum_velocity

  def number_of_wheels(self):
    return self.number_of_wheels

  def set_number_of_wheels(self, number):
    self.number_of_wheels = number

  def make_noise(self):
    print('VRUUUUUUUM')

Using this class

tesla_model_s = Vehicle(4, 'electric', 5, 250)
tesla_model_s.make_noise() # VRUUUUUUUM

Exercise

Write a student class (Name, Mark) with one method which return if the student pass/fail the test (mark >=? 10)

https://repl.it/@mokhleselheni/Student?lite=true

Lesson.Name: Python
Lesson.Content:
Python

Python is a "high-level" programming language and its core design philosophy is all about code readability and a syntax which allows programmers to express concepts in a few lines of code” created by Guido van Rossum.

In this course we will use an online code editor so no installation required.

Hello World

In our academy page, switch to code view and type

print("Hello Python!")

https://repl.it/@mokhleselheni/HelloPython?lite=true

Slides.Name: Variables
Slides.Content:
Variables

You can think about variables as a box that stores a value. Simple as that.

# booleans
true_boolean = True # T (uppercase) not t!
false_boolean = False # F not f!

# string
my_name = "Leandro Tk"

# float
book_price = 15.80

Slides.Name: Conditions
Slides.Content:
Control Flow: conditional statements

If a condition is True do something otherwise do another thing else.

if 1 > 2:
  print("1 is greater than 2")
else:
  print("1 is not greater than 2")

You can also use “elif” statement. Like that:

if 1 > 2:
  print("1 is greater than 2")
elif 2 > 1:
  print("1 is not greater than 2")
else:
  print("1 is equal to 2")

Slides.Name: Looping
Slides.Content:
Execute n lines of code until the condition turn to False

num = 1

while num <= 10:
  print(num)
  num += 1

For each element of a list do something

for i in range(1, 11):
  print(i)
  • range is a function that return a list from the first arg to 2nd (the 2nd not included).

Exercise

Ask the user to enter two integers (x and y) both should be greater than 0. Print which integer is bigger x or y.

Slides.Name: Lists
Slides.Content:
List: Collection | Array

my_integers = [5, 7, 3, 4, 4]

To take an element of the array and manipulate it we use indexes like this

print(my_integers[0]) # 5
print(my_integers[1] + my_integers[4]) # 7 + 4 = 11

To add an element to our list we use append()

bookshelf = []
bookshelf.append("The Effective Engineer")
bookshelf.append("The 4 Hour Work Week")
print(bookshelf[0]) # The Effective Engineer
print(bookshelf[1]) # The 4 Hour Work Week

Tuples

Lists that cannot be changed, just another thing () in place of [].

  a = (1, 2, "string", [])
  print(a[2])

Slides.Name: Dicts
Slides.Content:
Dictionary: Key-Value Data Structure

dictionary_example = {
  "key1": "value1",
  "key2": "value2",
  "key3": "value3"
}

Now we manipulate an element of our Dictionary using its key:

print("My name is %s" %(dictionary_tk["name"])) # My name is Leandro

Looping a Dictionary

for key, value in dictionary.items():
    print("%s --> %s" %(key, value))

Exercise:

Create a French to English Translator.

https://repl.it/@mokhleselheni/DictFrToEn?lite=true

Slides.Name: Function and Classes
Slides.Content:
Functions

def sum_of_2(arg1, arg2):
  result = arg1 * arg2
  return result

res = sum_of_2(2, 3)
print(res)

OOP

class Vehicle:
  def __init__(self, number_of_wheels, type_of_tank, seating_capacity, maximum_velocity):
    self.number_of_wheels = number_of_wheels
    self.type_of_tank = type_of_tank
    self.seating_capacity = seating_capacity
    self.maximum_velocity = maximum_velocity

  def number_of_wheels(self):
    return self.number_of_wheels

  def set_number_of_wheels(self, number):
    self.number_of_wheels = number

  def make_noise(self):
    print('VRUUUUUUUM')

Using this class

tesla_model_s = Vehicle(4, 'electric', 5, 250)
tesla_model_s.make_noise() # VRUUUUUUUM

Exercise

Write a student class (Name, Mark) with one method which return if the student pass/fail the test (mark >=? 10)

https://repl.it/@mokhleselheni/Student?lite=true
